sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving acids and bases
message_1: What is the standard enthalpy change for the reaction between hydrochloric acid (HCl) and sodium hydroxide (NaOH) to form sodium chloride (NaCl) and water (H2O)? Provide the balanced chemical equation for the reaction and show all calculations necessary to determine the standard enthalpy change.
message_2:
The balanced chemical equation for the reaction between hydrochloric acid (HCl) and sodium hydroxide (NaOH) to form sodium chloride (NaCl) and water (H2O) is:

HCl(aq) + NaOH(aq) → NaCl(aq) + H2O(l)

To determine the standard enthalpy change (ΔH°) for this reaction, we can use the standard enthalpies of formation (ΔHf°) for each of the compounds involved. The standard enthalpy of formation is the change in enthalpy when one mole of a substance is formed from its constituent elements in their standard states.

ΔH° = [ΔHf°(NaCl) + ΔHf°(H2O)] - [ΔHf°(HCl) + ΔHf°(NaOH)]

The standard enthalpies of formation for the compounds are as follows:

ΔHf°(HCl) = -167.2 kJ/mol
ΔHf°(NaOH) = -425.6 kJ/mol
ΔHf°(NaCl) = -411.1 kJ/mol
ΔHf°(H2O) = -285.8 kJ/mol

Now, we can plug these values into the equation:

ΔH° = [(-411.1) + (-285.8)] - [(-167.2) + (-425.6)]
ΔH° = (-696.9) - (-592.8)
ΔH° = -104.1 kJ/mol

Therefore, the standard enthalpy change for the reaction between hydrochloric acid and sodium hydroxide to form sodium chloride and water is -104.1 kJ/mol.
